input: Reflect on the resilience, adaptivity, and care of Oberlin's students in the context of COVID-19.
output:
Mid-march of this year, we all had to pack our bags and adjust to a new normal, scrambling to understand what it means to live, learn, and create art in the time of COVID. Students coping with the shock of relocation. Faculty adapting to the shift of virtual teaching. Those still in Oberlin dealt with a campus laid bare. All grieving for rituals lost.

Yet, as the spring and summer unfolded, and in the wake of social and cultural revolution, Oberlin’s students resilience, adaptivity, and care shines through. Watch our Department reflect on possibilities of art in this moment.

Students, welcome back to this new year! Let’s make the best of it.

🎥Clarissa Heart

🎤 James\xa0Dryden
Lauren Elwood
Sophie Falvey\xa0
Cass Gutterman-Johns
Clarissa Heart
Alex Howell
Daniel Fleischer

Music Credit:
A Perceptible Shift” by Andy G. Cohen is licensed under CC BY 4.0
“Brand New World” by Kai Engel is licensed under CC BY 4.0

#OberlinCollege #OberlinCollegeTheater

input: Share participation in a rally for public transit funding.
output:
Oberlin Sunrise joined groups in Cleveland this past Sunday to fight for public transit funding in the Build Back Better Act. It was wet but we had a great turnout and fantastic energy! Public transit is important both from an energy-use perspective and a justice perspective! With clean public transportation, everyone can have equal access to a city’s resources. Thank you to everyone who showed up and joined in our fight for transit justice, we are excited to continue work on this issue and others!

Photo by Solomon Freilich; license: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY)

#SunriseMovement #BuildBackBetter #PublicTransit #TransitJustice #Rally #GreenNewDeal

input: Highlight the achievements of Nicole Hernandez Hammer.
output:
Today we are featuring Nicole Hernandez Hammer, a Latinx woman conducting research on climate change. At the age of four, she immigrated to the United States from Guatemala. She received a degree in biology and investigates the disproportionate effects of the rise of sea levels on communities of color and low-income communities. In particular, she is dedicated to spreading and increasing the accessibility of knowledge about climate change to Latinx populations and advocating for more research towards climate change. Hernandez Hammer has also held several positions that have contributed to her advocacy, which include being the Florida field manager for Moms Clean Air Force and assistant director of the Florida Center for Environmental Studies at Florida Atlantic University. We acknowledge and are grateful for Nicole Hernandez Hammer’s excellence in research and advocacy!

#diversity #oberlin #research #legacy

input: Promote the Posse Foundation's expansion to recruit from Houston.
output:
The Posse Foundation works with Oberlin College to recruit and provide full tuition scholarships to a small group of 10 students with diverse backgrounds every year. Students work with four college mentors and the foundation to secure internships and career opportunities throughout the year. At Oberlin, the Posse Foundation has recruited their students exclusively from Chicago, but recently, Oberlin has announced the expansion of the program to recruit from Houston as well. The first Posse Scholars from Houston will begin studies alongside the 19th Chicago cohort. 

“We are proud of our long and productive history with the Posse Foundation, and we will recruit Chicago Posse #18 this year,” Manuel Carballo, vice president and dean of Admissions and Financial Aid, wrote in an email to the Review. “We recruited our first Posse cohort in 2006 and have welcomed more than 170 Posse Scholars to campus since then. The Admissions Office works with a number of community-based organizations and programs that help us find amazing, talented students who might not otherwise be exposed to colleges like Oberlin.”

The College has received a $500,000, five-year grant that will help expand into Houston and strengthen Oberlin’s commitment to the program. This will allow for 10 students to be selected from both Houston and Chicago, with the process starting in December 2024. There are currently four Chicago Posse cohorts on campus, with the 18th group being recruited this year. The goal is to add eight mentors and four cohorts from Houston by 2028.

📰Article by Nikki Keating
📷Photo courtesy of Scott Shaw

input: Celebrate Natasha Katz's honorary degree and Tony Award nominations.
output: This year, Oberlin College will be presenting an honorary degree to Natasha Katz ‘81, a Tony award-winning lighting designer. Last year, she earned her 7th Tony win and 15th nomination for her lighting design of MJ: The Musical. She has over 65 Broadway show credits and extensive credits in the worlds of dance, opera, concerts, and film. Natasha is on the board of the American Theatre Wing and was inducted into the Theatre Hall of Fame in 2019. You can read the college’s full article on the honorary degree recipients linked in our bio! As of this morning’s @thetonyawards nominations announcement, she has received two nominations for her lighting designs of Some Like It Hot and Sweeney Todd, her 16th and 17th Tony Award nominations. Congratulations to Natasha and make sure to watch this year’s Tony Awards on June 11! ✨

input: Introduce the character Sharlene.
output:
✨Character Spotlight✨
Sharlene is a high school graduate living with her family in rural wisconsin. She is a caring, kind, and considerate friend and often throughout the play acts as the maternal figure in the friend group. She’s deeply passionate about her relationship with God, and values morality and empathy above all. Sharlene is played by Emily Newmark.

input: Introduce our ambassador Kari
output:
Our second OUR ambassador is Kari! 

Hi y’all! My name is Kari Allen (she/her) and I am a 4th year Africana Studies and Psychology double major. I am the Humanities RA for OUR. As a researcher I am a Mellon Mays undergraduate fellow and I do psychology research in Professor Wu’s lab. Outside of research I am co chair of Drag Ball and enjoy cooking, napping, and singing. My office hours are Thursday from 3-5 in CELA!

output: Come to the first AAA meeting this Friday, October 7th from 5-6:30pm in Wilder Main! Come to orient yourself about the issues and topics that AAA will be tackling this semester and be political with your peers. Asians are welcome, apoliticism is not.

input: Announce applications for The Synapse Issue 34
output:
📢 ISSUE 34 is now accepting applications❗

Are you a student at Oberlin, Denison, CWRU, or Wooster and love writing, art, editing, and the world of science?

Apply now to contribute to The Synapse Issue 34! It is an excellent way to cultivate skills in science writing and editing. The Synapse presents an invaluable opportunity to collaborate with students from different colleges and disciplines.

Writer - Interested in science or science fiction writing? Want to share cutting-edge research, exciting developments, and intersections, or problems in the field? Ever wanted someone to illustrate your writing? Apply to write a one or two-page article!

Artist - Interested in publishing your artwork? Want to create content that makes science accessible and relevant? Apply to paint, draw, sketch, illustrate, or photograph for The Synapse!

Editor- Interested in honing your critical eye? Want to work closely with writers to help them communicate their brilliant ideas effectively? Apply to be a content or copy editor!

Layout editor - (Oberlin College Only) Enjoy formatting layouts or want to learn how to use InDesign? No experience necessary! Apply to be a layout editor!

Applications for Issue 34 are due by Sunday, October 2nd, 2022 at 11:59 PM EST. Find out more information on our website: https://synapsemagazine.org/.

input: Announce Poker Tournament event hosted by CardCo and The 'Sco
output:
CardCo and the 'Sco are hosting their second ever Poker Tournament.

The night will run like this:
8:30PM - Beginners Poker Lesson

9:00PM - Doors open for everyone to join and find a seat at a table.
Tables 1–3 Beginners
Tables 4–6 Intermediate
Tables 7–8 Advanced

9:20PM–9:50PM - Play Poker! The person from each table with the most amount of chips at the end of the 30 minute game will advance to the Winners Table.

10:10PM–10:40PM - Winners Table round! & Exhibition Fun Tables. The person at the Winners Table with the highest amount of chips at the end of this 30 minute game will have the first pick of the prizes, the person with the second-highest amount of chips will have second pick, and so on.

11:00PM - Finish

input: Announce event featuring Dr. Ronan Lee and Dr. Harrison Akins
output:
Please join us on Thursday, March 14, for an event featuring Dr. Ronan Lee and Dr. Harrison Akins! Both are academics, and will speak about their experiences in governance and research in their respective fields of expertise. 

There will be individual sessions from 1-3, a joint lecture from 5-7 (with refreshments included!), and a special Iftar dinner afterwards from 7-10. Follow the link in our bio to RSVP for the Iftar! Otherwise, no RSVPs are needed for the events, both of which will be in the AJLC’s Hallock Auditorium.

Massive thanks to the African Students Association and the Asian American Alliance for co-hosting this event, and to the Politics Department, History Department, Shansi, and the Multicultural Resource Commons for being sponsors. We’d also like to extend our gratitude to the Christ Episcopal Church for hosting our Iftar dinner!

input: Promote 'Big Spender' theater production
output:
Big Spender’s Artistic Director and Costume Designer Katie Homer-Drummond ‘22: 

“When designing this show, it was important to both Lauren and I to try to achieve a sense of authenticity amongst the magic of the glamour and the lights.

I read several statements and interviews from former or current cam girls, and what seemed essential to recreate was this sense of a space within a space. An area that looked and felt different from the rest of their rooms so it was easy to distinguish between a work environment and a home environment. 

In order to achieve that each space, regardless of if they share some characteristics, is unique in layout and setup, and a lot of the time have been expanded with items from the dancers personal collections. Each set and costume is inspired by the dancer's unique characters they created with the lighting and color pallete acting as a unifying element.“

To see more of Homer-Drummond’s initial design concepts, head over to @bigbadspender.

Seen above: a collage of the initial design board for Big Spender’s costume design.

You can register NOW to see Big Spender which will be available to watch February 19 - 21 at the link in our bio.

input: Promote LabSeries 'Calypso' theater production
output:
Next up in our LabSeries is Calypso, written and directed by Jordan Muschler ‘23, opening in one month! There is a lot going on in April so get your tickets now for these performances 🌅
— 
Abandoned by the Gods, Calypso is stuck on an island alone and longing for more. A sudden storm strikes and brings with it a man, Odysseus, who has lived the life she wishes to lead. As the two grow closer, Calypso realizes she cannot go back to being alone. 
— 
Poster design: Hannah Dougall

input: Announce summer publishing schedule for The Review
output:
The Review would like to announce that we are publishing this summer on a rolling basis! We are committed to covering the issues and events that are important to Oberlin College & Conservatory and the Oberlin community during Covid-19 and the ongoing nationwide protests against police brutality.
We’re accepting Op-eds and Letters to the Editor, in addition to other journalistic writing. You can reach out to opinions@oberlinreview.org with Opinions submissions, as well as edsinchief@oberlinreview.org or managingeditor@oberlinreview.org to be added to our writing listserv, to pitch a story, or to hear more. 
We would like to emphasize our availability as a platform to amplify voices in the Oberlin community, and Black voices in particular, during this time. Please reach out if you’re interested in having your writing or a statement from your organization appear on our website.

input: Promote Latine voice night event
output:
In case you missed our weekly…(which like…cmon LOOK at it, it’s so cute 🥰) we are hosting a Latine voice night this October‼️ This performance space is open to the entire Latin American diaspora, including staff & faculty! We hope this night serves as a way to get to know our community in a more intimate setting while showcasing our talents. What you share/decide to do is completely up your imagination, and we hope to see you there <3

Click the link in bio or scan this QR code for more information & to sign up!

input: Announce Big Parade event
output: Big Parade is back! We will be hosting our first parade since 2019 on Saturday, May 14th! The theme is FEAST so get ready for some fun food floats! The route will begin at Eastwood elementary school, go down College Street, and end at the Southwest corner of Taplan Square. As always, there will be a festival with a barbecue and music in Tappan Square right after the parade. We are so excited to be back and can’t wait to see you there! If you would like to be in the parade or construct a parade float, e-mail biggest.parade@gmail.com or message us here on Instagram or Facebook.

input: Share information from Minnesota Indian Women’s Sexual Assault Coalition
output:
CW: mention of rape, sexual assault, childhood sexual abuse, and trauma experiences following the aftermath of harm

Sharing this incredibly important information from the Minnesota Indian Women’s Sexual Assault Coalition @miwsac 

Image description:
1) Sexual Violence: A Public Health Issue for Native People. Impacts of sexual violence: Disconnect with spirit, culture, or self. Physical injury - lasting short or long term. Trauma, hyper-vigilance, flashbacks. Difficulty trusting or believing others. Entire medicine wheel: spiritual, physical, emotional, mental. 

2) Sexual violence is pervasive. American Indians are 2.5 times more likely to experience sexual assault compared to all other races. 34% of Native women are raped in their lifetimes. At least 84% of perpetrators of these crimes are non-Native men. 

3) Sexual violence and trauma. Following an assault, common outcomes include poor mental health (PTSD, acute stress disorders, depression, sleep disorders, anxiety, suicidal ideation). Decreased sexual urges/pleasure, increased sexual risk behaviors, substance use and physical health problems. Revitalization (is) also commonly reported for Indigenous survivors of childhood sexual abuse. 

4) Sexual Violence is Preventable. Protective factors positively associated with health and social outcomes for American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) youth include: Personal wellness, positive self-image, self-efficacy, familial and non-familial connectedness, positive opportunities, positive social norms, cultural connectedness.

input: Announce open call for auditions for 'The Death of Midas'
output:
An open call for “The Death of Midas” is on Saturday September 10th from 12:00 - 4:00 pm in Studio 3 of the Warner Center. Everyone who wants to audition for the production is welcome, including those who have not yet submitted a video audition. 

The Death of Midas, written by Owen Anderson, is an ensemble piece; storytelling focused on collective creation. Performers will devise portions of the show. The responsibility of embodying each character will be shared across the ensemble by passing roles between performers throughout the play. The play is an adaptation: a story about King Midas, as well as The Purple Flower, a play by Marita Bonner.

From the Directors: At its core, our show follows a fractured community trying to heal from the systematic oppression of the tyrant King Midas. Because of this, we’re especially wanting to work with actors of color; very excited to see you on Saturday!

input: Share information about allegations against Professor Mohammad Jafar Mahallati
output: A very important conversation is happening on campus and it is vital for all of the Oberlin community to be aware of it. We prepared a series of info graphs on the allegations brought against Professor of Religion and Nancy Schrom Dye Chair in Middle East and North African Studies Mohammad Jafar Mahallati. We will be sharing more info every day of this week. Join the conversation that will shape the history of Oberlin and share your thoughts in the comments below.

input: Promote SOSHA’s Resource Library for Men & Masculine Survivors
output:
Plugging SOSHA’s Resource Library!

Resources for Men & Masculine Survivors:
Articles, Books, Community Orgs, Podcasts, and More

TINYURL.COM/SOSHAMenResources

*Assume content warnings for all for mentions of stigma around male survivors, sexual harm and resulting trauma*

READ: 
* “Op Ed: The Ohio State Scandal Should Be A Wake-Up Call: Men Are Also Victims of Sexual Abuse” by Lara Stemple
* “Op Ed: Building Back Trust and Finding My Voice After Sexual Abuse” by Alec Govi
* “A Survivor’s Tale of Sexual Abuse Draws Attention to the Plight of Male Victims” by Jeff McMillan
* “The Abercrombie & Fitch Documentary is a Timely Reminder that Male Victims Exist - And Their Stories Matter” by Chloe Laws

Transparent by Don Lemon
Wherever I Wind Up: My Quest for Truth, Authenticity, and The Perfect Knuckleball by R.A. Dickey and Wayne Coffey
Never Let Me Go by Chuck Rosenthal

LISTEN:
“The Bristlecone Project”
“Boys and Men Healing”
Texas Men’s Story Project
“Reimagining Masculinity: My Journey as a Male Sexual Assault Survivor” by Landon Wilcock
“Nature, Nurture, and Our Evolving Debates About Gender”

And More! Link in Bio or at TINYURL.COM/SOSHAMenResources

input: Feature Nora Holder's article series 'Happy as Her'
